title: NixOS Package PRs for exfatprogs, pam_u2f, diffutils, nixos, attr-2.5.1, gnugrep-3.7 packages
description: NixOS Package PRs for exfatprogs, pam_u2f, diffutils, nixos, attr-2.5.1, gnugrep-3.7 packages on GitHub

items.content_html:
Description of changes

create a module to use qbitTorrent as a service.

blocking issues

  • sufficient testing ( some testing is done, imo not enough.)
  • serverConfig
    • gendeepINI gets a fitting type to use for this option.
      qBittorrent from editing the config file if we want to define it ourselves.
    • qBittorrent.conf can be set as a symlink in the given location without being overwritten by the program. ( done with 1 sticky bit, this behaviour in qBittorrent of overwriting the path is annoying, but this deals with it well enough )
  • openFirewall
  • release notes entry ( currently unsure on formatting)

nice to haves

  • a better way to set CapabilityBoundingSet to restrict all.
  • an explanation for PrivateTmp being disabled upstream. ( qbittorrent/qBittorrent#6806 (comment) )
  • some way to generate the unique password format used.

notes

for service hardening I don't believe any of the following can be used simply because of the services purpose.
IPAddressDeny PrivateNetwork or restriction of AF_NETLINK AF_INET or AF_INET6 address families.
ProtectSystem cant be used without entirely declarative config

in my previous attempt at this here i was advised to simply make use of the service from the package, I'm unsure how to do this.
I started with an aim to follow https://github.com/qbittorrent/qBittorrent/blob/master/dist/unix/systemd/qbittorrent-nox%40.service.in I don't understand why it sets PrivateTmp to false however and have otherwise changed it significantly with service hardening and nix(os) specifics.

testing so far has been made following #279716

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Logiops is third-party software for configuring Logitech mice, e.g remapping buttons or scroll behavior. It is already packaged in nixpkgs, but there is no systemd service associated with it.

Closes #226575

Note: I'm not quite sure how to write tests for this service, so any help in that department would be much appreciated!

items.title: nixos-rebuild: avoid --preserve-env

items.content_html:
Description of changes

  • add inMemoryState

this causes tailscale to make the registration ephemeral. I use this for booting the nixos installer (which auto-runs sudo tailscale up --qr), and this ensures that the hostname get reused, instead of suffixed.

Also, it's just nice to not need to manually cleanup tailscale hosts from the admin panel, when I know some are going to be ephemeral by nature anyway.

definitely open to feedback about naming the option.

items.title: nixos/transfer-sh: init

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Currently, firewall.allowed* options apply to all interfaces. If the user wants to exclude a specific interface from opening ports, they must not define any open ports with firewall.allowed* options and instead define open ports for every single interface individually (using firewall.interfaces.<interface>.allowed*).

This is not very practical as if a user wants all ports on a single interface closed whilst keeping configured ports on all other interfaces open, the rest of the configuration has to become more verbose. Additionally, modules that open firewall ports using firewall.allowed* will not work in this scenario.

The defaultInterfaces option fixes this by allowing users to define a list of interfaces that firewall.allow* options should exclusively apply to. This way it's possible to use the firewall.allow* options (for default interfaces such as ethernet and wireless) whilst also having specific interfaces (such as a VPN) where the firewall does not open ports unless explicitly told to do so with firewall.interfaces.<interface>.

This is not a breaking change as when firewall.defaultInterfaces is not defined, the firewall is configured exactly the same as it was before.

items.title: nixos/lldap: make user configurable

items.content_html:
Description of changes

...effectively what was planned already in #266270, but it was too late because the branches were restricted and didn't allow any breaking changes anymore.

It also suffers from the same issue that we already had when discussing this the last time[1] when ensureDBOwnership was ultimately introduced as band-aid fix: newly created users don't get CREATE permission on the public schema anymore (since psql 15), even with ALL PRIVILEGES.

If one's use-case is more sophisticated than having a single owner, it's questionable anyways if this module is the correct tool since permissions aren't dropped on a change to this option or a removal which is pretty surprising in the context of NixOS.

[1] #266270

items.title: nixos/obs-studio: init

items.content_html:
Description of changes

We remove scripted initrd networking as it is:

  • very much broken, see https://fem.social/@clerie/111890928880190411
  • almost unsalvageable as all boot people are working on the systemd stage 1
  • has de-facto no maintainer

Signed-off-by: Raito Bezarius masterancpp@gmail.com

TODO:

  • fix all tests
  • sprinkle enough warnings

I have scripted initrd usecases, what's going to happen to me?

Please consider using the systemd stage 1 setup, if you have troubles, reach out to the support channel. If this is a real showstopper, please chime in this discussion.

Open to pick up to external contributors :

  • Transform this PR into a warning-only PRs and prepare the drop PR for 24.05 branch-off for a full release cycle of deprecation: I don't suggest it because there's no maintainer and this just cause maintenance churn on the systemd stage 1 side.

  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)

items.title: nixos: drop scripted initrd networking

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This builds on top of #278969. It provides two main features to NixOS related to the Container Device Interface (CDI):

  • virtualisation.containers.cdi.static attrset of JSONs. This can be used to provide static valid JSON files for CDI that will be placed under /etc/cdi.

  • virtualisation.containers.cdi.dynamic.nvidia.enable boolean. When enabled, it will use the nvidia-container-toolkit to generate a CDI spec based on the current machine, as a systemd unit file. The generated JSON file will be patched to accomodate the NixOS host system, and will be placed under /run/cdi/nvidia-container-toolkit.json.

As per the CDI spec, CDI-compliant runtimes need to inspect /etc/cdi (static configuration) and /var/run/cdi (dynamic configuration); prioritizing what is under the dynamic configuration over the static configuration in case of clash.

So, this implementation is compliant with this specification.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)

    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages

items.title: NixOS: Add support for CDI

items.content_html:
The base URL GUI option of Ombi is known to be broken, which is very inconvenient for reverse proxying with subfolders. The suggested method (in Ombi's documentation) is to pass the --baseurl command-line parameter.

Description of changes

This commit thus adds an option to set this parameter to the NixOS Ombi module.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)

items.title: nixos/ombi: add baseUrl option

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Adds networking.machineId, which is very useful when running e.g. a impermanence setup, or generally for persisting the machine ID.
The machine ID is now also used to generate the host ID, if it is not already set.

I've also changed the zfs test to use networking.machineId instead of machine.hostId, and ran the test which works as expected.

Sorry for the ZFS maintainers this might request review for, this is not my intention.

@lilyinstarlight can you review this?
